description.narrative: The project goal is to address the environmental, social and economic insecurities in the most vulnerable communities of the Aral Sea.

participating-org.narrative: MPTF-Multi-Partner Human Security Trust Fund for the Aral Sea Region in Uzbekistan (MPHSTF)

activity-description.narrative: At the same time, given the specificity of the activities related to the promotion of sustainable tourism, activities of this sub-component will cover not only Takhtakupir, but also Muynak and Chimbay districts of Karakalpakstan.

In order to increase the effectiveness of the proposed interventions, the project will geographically focus in the Takhtakupir district of Karakalpakstan, which is considered as one of the least developed districts of the region. description.narrative: seat of a second-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: In order to increase the effectiveness of the proposed interventions, the project will geographically focus in the Takhtakupir district of Karakalpakstan, which is considered as one of the least developed districts of the region.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

provider-org.narrative: MPTF-Multi-Partner Human Security Trust Fund for the Aral Sea Region in Uzbekistan (MPHSTF)

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

comment.narrative:
1.1.1. Preparatory activities on renovation of the premises of water distribution station completed. [3] project estimation documents prepared. 1.1.2. Procurement and delivery of the artesian water purification equipment and reconstruction of water purification compound completed; 100% of construction works completed. [175] people received access to safe drinking water in Tazakonis community by late October. 1.2.1. Installation of water pipelines in the Beltau Center community is fully completed. [878] people received access to safe drinking water in Beltau Center community by late October.
1.3.1. Installation of water pipelines Mulik community has been fully completed. [1178] people received access to safe drinking water in Mulik community by middle of October.
1.4.1. A National Consultant has been hired to research the establishment of the “Drinking Water Association (DWA)”. Based on the research analysis, establishing of [1] DWA has been considered impractical and duplication of the State water supply institute role. Instead, it was recommended to utilize the financial resources for realization of additional water projects. Two more water purification equipment with capacities of 8 and 10 cubic/meters per hour have been purchased and installed in “Marjankol” (525p) and “Janadarya” (735p) communities. 1.4.2. The project National Consultant has regularly visited the project site and held informal training sessions with community members on proper maintenance of the installed water system, its effective use, hygiene rules; training of [20] people on proper use of water system completed in November. 1.4.3. A National Consultant has been hired for development of WASH procedures; [150] people trained on proper sanitation and hygiene norms; [100] sanitation and hygiene materials developed and distributed late October.
2.1.1 [6] new income generation projects are selected by Review Committee for co-financing, namely: Fodder production, Milk processing, Straw mat/board production, Soap production, Halva-kozinaki production and Dentistry facility development. Procurement of necessary equipment is in process. Over [35] people are expected to benefit through new job creation and having access to produced goods and provided services. 2.1.2. [25] people (52% women and youth) enhanced skills though training on value chain management at livestock sector and fundamentals of business planning and entrepreneurship development. [25] women and girls had a training on basics of entrepreneurship and business development. [20] owners of SMEs in Takhtakupir district had training on strategy formulation, value-chain analysis and taxation. While for [5] SMEs strategy has been developed. Total number of people enhanced skills [70]. 2.1.3. 3 business projects led by women/girls are being supported, namely: Soap production, Halva-kozinaki production and rural Dentistry facility development. 3 business projects expected to create [15] new job places among women/girls at the initial stage and increase up to [35] at later stage.
3.1.1. Two rounds of scientific expeditions (First Expedition in Sep-Oct 2019; Second expedition May-June 2020) on monitoring dried bed of the Aral Sea conducted. The expedition was comprised of the team of 13 people including the experts and support staff (soil scientists, environment, afforestation, plant science, hydrology, GIS and Remote Sensing specialists) from SIC ICWC and International Aral Sea Innovation Center. Currently, the analysis of soil and underground water samples expedition is completed. The Final Expedition Report available, book “Monitoring of dried bed of Aral Sea” is designed; Round table on 2 scientific expeditions organized in the 16th December, 2020 to present to the partners and stakeholders about the results of 2 scientific expeditions and introduce Book “Monitoring of dried bed of Aral Sea” 3.1.2. National Consultant on Training Coordination and Monitoring is to be recruited. Needs assessment on the capacity building amongst the staff of the State Forestry Committee of the Republic of Karakalpakstan and its 16 branches conducted. Based on needs, Project, in cooperation with the International Innovation Center for the Aral sea basin under the President of the Republic of Uzbekistan organized 2-day training through ZOOM platform due to COVID-19 lockdown for over [100] afforestation specialists of the State Forestry Committee and its 16 branches throughout on following 4 thematic areas in December: (i) Inventory of forested areas using GIS technology; (ii) Development and introduction of a system of measures for protecting the seeds of trees and shrubs against pests and diseases; (iii) Development of measures to promote the natural renewal of forestry crops in tugai forests; (iv) Development and implementation of innovative methods of afforestation in drought prone areas.
Trained afforestation specialists expected to share/disseminate knowledge on obtained innovative methods of afforestation with local farmers, dehkans and pasture cooperatives members in districts. Purchased and delivered radio telephones for field communications, a truck for transporting seeds and seedlings, an excavator-bulldozer, mobile wagon houses for shift teams complete with diesel generator sets, heaters, air conditioning systems, as well as tents, field ovens, tarpaulins; At the stage of delivery, welding units on wheels, food tanks on a trailer, a tanker trailer; Contracted square baler, tractor trailers, tractors, long-base planner, digging plows and delivery expected in February 2021;
These measures will help plant saxaul on 500 hectares of land on the drained bottom of the Aral Sea and create a nursery on 49 hectares of land for growing seedlings from drought-resistant plants.

1.1.1. Project estimation document prepared on installation of water pipeline in Janadarya community of Takhtakupir district;
1.1.2. Installation of water pipeline network 4 km length completed in April 2021. [735] rural inhabitants have access to clean drinking water at homes. In total during 2019-2021, six projects on access to clean drinking implemented in 5 rural communities, 3,491 people have access to drinking water.
2.1.1 [13] new income generation projects are selected by Review Committee for co-financing, namely: Fodder production, Milk processing, Straw mat/board production, Soap production, Halva-kozinaki production, Dentistry facility development, bakery and dumpling. Procurement of all equipment completed in May 2021. Over [50] people benefit through new job creation and having access to produced goods and provided services. 2.1.2. [50] people (52% women and youth) enhanced skills though training on value chain management at livestock sector and fundamentals of business planning and entrepreneurship development. [20] women and girls had a training on basics of entrepreneurship and business development. [45] owners of SMEs in Takhtakupir district had training on strategy formulation, value-chain analysis and taxation. While for [5] SMEs strategy has been developed. Total number of people enhanced skills [115]. 2.1.3. 13 business projects mostly led by women/girls supported, namely: Soap production, Halva-kozinaki production, rural Dentistry facility development, poultry, dumpling, bakery and etc. 13 business projects created [50] new job places among women/girls and 5,537 people have access to goods produced and services provided.
3.1.1. Two rounds of scientific expeditions (First Expedition in Sep-Oct 2019; Second expedition May-June 2020) on monitoring dried bed of the Aral Sea conducted. The expedition was comprised of the team of 13 people including the experts and support staff (soil scientists, environment, afforestation, plant science, hydrology, GIS and Remote Sensing specialists) from SIC ICWC and International Aral Sea Innovation Center. Currently, the analysis of soil and underground water samples expedition is completed. The Final Expedition Report available in the form of book “Monitoring of dried bed of Aral Sea” in English and Russian is designed, published and disseminated among partner organizations. Relevant information on GIS mapping, remote sensing and other are available in Book; 3.2.1. Based on the assessment results the JP identified demand for 17 types of essential machinery and equipment, which included a mobile home to be used in remote areas during afforestation works, a welding machine on wheels, a bus truck, storage tanks on wheels for water and petrol, tents and sleeping bags. Bidding for procurement was completed in 2020. By the end of 2020, some of the machinery and equipment was delivered to the Takhtakupir Forestry Department, namely radio telephones for field communications, a truck for transporting seeds and seedlings, an excavator-bulldozer, mobile homes with diesel generators, heaters, air conditioning systems, and also tents, field ovens, tarpaulins and welding units on wheels. Other machinery such as food tanks on a trailer, a tanker trailer, a square baler, tractor trailers, tractors, long-base planner and excavation plows, was delivered in May 2021. These measures helped to plant saxaul in over 3000 hectares of land on the drained bottom of the Aral Sea compared to 100-150 hectares the start, and create a nursery on 49 hectares of land for growing seedlings from drought-resistant plants compared to 2-3 hectares before, with 142 additional hectares expected to be developed. Technical support provided to 3 pasture cooperatives for development of nurseries on drought-resistant plants in 58 hectares of pasture areas.

Supporting the initiatives on afforestation of the dried Sea bed through organization of 1 scientific expedition to the dried bed of the Aral Sea, which will result in the development of the full set of data including GIS mapping and remote sensing, and availability of research driven data on soil composition of land on the dried bed of the Aral Sea;

The 1st scientific expedition on the dried Sea bed completed: - 12 national and 1 international consultants were involved - ecologists, soil scientists, botanists, hydrogeologists, GIS and remote sensing specialists. - 1st expedition conducted from 20 September to 20 October 2019, covering the southern part of the dried Sea bed in the region of Muynak, Adzhibay Bay in the western part, in the vicinity of Sudochye Lake, north of the Tigris Tail and along the Ustyurt Chink. - The expedition travelled 2,500 kilometres, laid 35 soil sections and described 1,570 points on various surface classes.
Results of the expedition:
Salt-resistant plants/seeds are planted immediately after preparing sand accumulating furrows. Due to premature planting works on furrows with no accumulated sand, the degree of survival of planted plants is not satisfactory.
Recommendation: After the second year of preparing sand accumulation furrows, it is necessary to conduct a study and wait until the amount of sand accumulation allows planting of forest crops. Aero sowing needs to be carried out on those areas where tamarix-karabarak thickets dry up and covered by sand.
Results of the expedition:
During the expedition, more than 30 species of plants from 1,500 different points of the dried bed of the Aral Sea identified.
The following promising plant species play key role in sand and salt stabilization: Black saxaul; Bristled hair comb Multi-branched comb Belanje saltwater Climakopter Aral Climacopter woolly Schoebert nurse; Dereza Russian; Quinoa Pratova; Bassia issopolistic Richters Solyanka
These types of plants are recommended for planting on the dried bed of the Aral Sea
